DOC.HEAD: Snow, Bitter Cold in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Winter officially began this afternoon, but it seems like it's already been here for a while for much of the nation already shivering under frigid temperatures. Temperatures dropped to well below zero from Wyoming to Michigan, and wind chills were expected today to be as low as 80 below in North Dakota, 75 below in Minnesota and 65 below in Missouri. Snow fell early today throughout the Midwest, blanketing parts of Missouri, Michigan, Illinois, Ohio and Indiana. A cold front continued to move south across the nation's midsection Wednesday afternoon. The southern edge of the cold air extended across western New York, central Ohio, southwest Indiana, northeast Missouri, southwest Iowa, north-central Kansas, northeast Colorado, northwest Wyoming and north-central Montana. The cold air was expected to reach northern Texas and northern Louisiana today, and to invade North Carolina and northern Georgia by Friday. A ``major freeze'' was predicted across the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas from tonight until Saturday. Winter storm warnings for heavy snow and wind were posted today for much of Michigan and northwest Pennsylvania. About a foot of snow was forecast for northwest upper Michigan. Snow also fell early today over Pittsburgh. Winter officially arrived at 4:22 p.m. EST today. Snow showers were scattered in central New England Wednesday evening. Snow also fell in western New York, northwest Pennsylvania, northeast Ohio, Michigan, northern Indiana, northern Illinois, Wisconsin, southern Minnesota, Iowa, northern Missouri, southern and western South Dakota, eastern and northern Nebraska, northeast Kansas, and parts of Wyoming, Montana and Washington state. The high temperature for the Lower 48 states Wednesday was 84 degrees in Florida at Hollywood, Homestead and Miami.
